2330614830.excerpt: In today’s video game industry, many companies try to sell players in-game content. Whether it be a personalized skin that’s purely cosmetic or an add-on item that increases the strength of a player’s character, players are persistently being marketed the newest and greatest items.

8.caption: In the case of Yu-Gi-Oh Duel Links, players start the game with a starter box and a set number of gems that they can use to spend on in-game booster packs. The game also uses the psychological tactic of scarcity

9.caption: The nucleus accumbens, highlighted by the red dot, is the part of the brain associated with pleasure

11.caption: Opening a loot box in Overwatch shoots the rewards into the air, where the color of the coins denotes their rarity. However, users don’t know exactly what item they’re getting, so the excitement gets amplified when the coins turn into the actual rewards.

12.caption: Hearthstone, another Blizzard game, does a really nice job of allowing players to figure out the rarity of an item when hovering their mouse over a card. This is another example of providing that extra layer of excitement when opening a new pack.

13.caption: The more time people invest into a game or product, the more willing they are to pay.

14.caption: An example of a limited time offer from Star Wars Commander, a free-to-play strategy game for mobile with in-game purchases.

2163704584.excerpt: As sometimes happens, I was thinking the other day. In this case, I was doing my thinking after finishing a long video game: Far Cry 5. It occurred to me that video game creators are the masters of emotional payoff, when everything goes right.
